sect2.title: Via Sendmail (default)
sect2.para: OTRS can send out emails via Sendmail (e. g. Sendmail, Postfix, Qmail or Exim). The default configuration to use Sendmail should work out of the box.
You can configure the sendmail settings via the graphical configuration frontend (Framework::Core::Sendmail) or via Kernel/Config.pm:

sect2.title: Via SMTP relay/smarthost
sect2.para: OTRS can send out emails via SMTP ( Simple Mail Transfer Protocol / RFC 821). This settings will mostly be needed on non unix platforms (e. g. win32).
The sendmail settings for a smarthost can be configured either via the graphical administration frontend (Framework::Core::Sendmail) or via Kernel/Config.pm:

sect2.title: Via POP3 accounts - the easy way (PostMasterPOP3.pl)
sect2.para: OTRS is able to receive emails from POP3 accounts.
Configure your POP3 accounts via the admin interface (POP3 Account).
Execute the command bin/PostMasterPOP3.pl and all emails will be fetched into your OTRS system.
There is also an example cronjob (var/cron/postmaster_pop3.dist) that executes your bin/PostMasterPOP3.pl every 10 minutes.

sect2.title: Via command line program and e. g. procmail (PostMaster.pl)
sect2.para: If POP3 can't be used to get the emails into OTRS, the commandline programm bin/PostMaster.pl might be a solution. bin/PostMaster.pl takes the mails via STDIN and pipes them directly into OTRS. That means emails will be shown in your OTRS system if the MDA (mail delivery agent, e. g. procmail) executes bin/PostMaster.pl
To test bin/PostMaster.pl without MDA on the command line execute the following command:

para.screen: linux:/opt/otrs# cd bin linux:/opt/otrs/bin# cat ../doc/test-email-1.box | ./PostMaster.pl linux:/opt/otrs/bin#

sect2.para: If the email is shown in the QueueView then your setup works fine.
Procmail is a very common e-mail filter in the Linux enviroment. It will be installed on most systems. If not, have a look at the procmail homepage.
To configure procmail for OTRS (requires a procmail configured MTA (e. g. sendmail, postfix, exim or qmail)) use the ~otrs/.procmailrc.dist file and copy it to .procmailrc. Add the following:

para.programlisting: SYS_HOME=$HOME PATH=/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin # -- # Pipe all email into the PostMaster process. # -- :0 : | $SYS_HOME/bin/PostMaster.pl

sect2.para: All emails sent to the local otrs user will be piped into bin/PostMaster.pl and then shown in your QueueView.

sect2.title: Fetching emails via POP3 or IMAP and fetchmail for PostMaster.pl
sect2.para: In order to get e-mails from your mail server via a POP3 or IMAP mailbox to the OTRS machine/local otrs account and to procmail use fetchmail.

note.para: A working SMTP configuration on the OTRS machine is required.

sect2.para: You can use the .fetchmailrc.dist in the home directory of OTRS and copy it to .fetchmailrc. Modfiy/change it for your needs.

para.programlisting: #poll (mailserver) protocol POP3 user (user) password (password) is (localuser) poll mail.example.com protocol POP3 user joe password mama is otrs

sect2.para: Don't forget to set the .fetchmailrc to 710 ("chmod 710 .fetchmailrc")!

With the .fetchmailrc from the example above, all e-mails will be forwarded to the local otrs account, if the command fetchmail -a is executed. Setup a cronjob with this command, if you want to fetch the mails regularyly.

sect2.title: Filtering/dispatching by OTRS/PostMaster modules (for more complex dispatching)
sect2.para:
If you use the bin/PostMaster.pl or bin/PostMasterPOP3.pl method, you can insert or modify X-OTRS header entries with the PostMaster filter modules. With the X-OTRS headers the ticket system can execute some actions on incomming mails, sort them into a specific queue, change the priority oder change the customer ID for example. More information about the X-OTRS headers are available in the chapter about
adding POP3 accounts
in the admin area of OTRS.
There exist some default filter modules:

note.para: The job name (e. g. $Self->{'PostMaster::PreFilterModule'}->{'JobName'}) needs to be unique!

sect2.para: Kernel::System::PostMaster::Filter::Match is a default module to match on some email header (e. g. From, To, Subject, ...). It can set new email headers (e. g. X-OTRS-Ignore: yes or X-OTRS-Queue: spam) if a filter rule matches. The following example jobs can be inserted in Kernel/Config.pm

example.title: Example jobs for the filter module Kernel::System::PostMaster::Filter::Match

sect2.para: Kernel::System::PostMaster::Filter::CMD is a default module to pipe the email into an external command. The output is given to STDOUT and if the result is true, then set new email header (e. g. X-OTRS-Ignore: yes or X-OTRS-Queue: spam). The following example can be used in Kernel/Config.pm

example.title: Example job for the filter module Kernel::System::PostMaster::Filter::CMD

sect2.para: Ofcourse it's also possible to develop own PostMaster filter modules.
